questions.text:
A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician’s office by his parents due to persistent crying and abdominal bloating. His parents noticed the patient’s abdomen appears swollen, and they think that he cries due to abdominal pain. They have tried to change his diet without relief. There is no history of recent infection, sick contacts or change in the color of his stool. The patient was born at term through normal vaginal birth and delivery. At birth, the patient was diagnosed with a right eye condition, but his parents can’t remember the name. His parents report that the patient does not yet smile at them or say “mama” or “dada,” and he mainly bables. The child can grasp toys with both hands but is unable to stand or walk. The results of the right eye examination are shown below.  


 
Reproduced from: flickr

Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be found on physical examination?
questions.solution:
This infant presenting with abdominal pain, developmental delay, and aniridia (absent iris) on eye examination most likely has WAGR syndrome. The abdominal pain and bloating that did not resolve with diet changes implies an abdominal mass, which along with other findings is most likely nephroblastoma.   

WAGR syndrome is characterized by Wilms tumor (nephroblastoma), Aniridia, Genitourinary anomalies, and intellectual disability (mental Retardation). In children with WAGR syndrome, there is approximately 50% risk of developing Wilms tumor. WAGR syndrome is caused by “loss of function” mutations of tumor suppressor gene WT1 located on chromosome 11. The WT1 gene product is a transcription factor that is involved in gonadal and renal development.  

Wilms tumor arises from proliferation of the embryonic metanephric blastema without normal tubular and glomerular differentiation. It is the most common renal malignancy of early childhood (ages 2–4) and may arise sporadically or as a part of a syndrome. Patients often present with a large, palpable, unilateral flank smooth mass that does not cross the midline and/or hematuria and possible hypertension.  

Option Analysis

❌ Macroglossia:
Incorrect: Macroglossia can be seen in Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome, a genetic disorder characterized by the development of Wilms tumor, macroglossia, organomegaly, hemihyperplasia. It is caused by WT2 mutation in the 11p15.5 region. Aniridia is not seen in this syndrome.   
❌ Gonadal dysgenesis :
Incorrect: Gonadal dysgenesis (specifically male pseudohermaphroditism) can be seen in Denys-Drash syndrome, a genetic disorder characterized by the development of Wilms tumor, diffuse mesangial sclerosis (early-onset nephrotic syndrome). It is caused by WT1 mutation. Aniridia is not seen in this syndrome.   
❌ Pheochromocytoma:
Incorrect: Pheochromocytoma can be seen in neurofibromatosis type I, a genetic disorder characterized by café-au-lait spots, lisch nodules (iris hamartoma), cutaneous neurofibromas, pheochromocytomas, and optic gliomas. This patient’s eye examination shows an absent iris rather than lisch nodules.   
✅ Nephroblastoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Nevus flammeus:
Incorrect: Nevus flammeus can be seen in Sturge-Weber syndrome, a congenital nonhereditary anomaly of neural crest derivatives characterized by nevus flammeus (port-wine stain), leptomeningeal angioma, intellectual disability, glaucoma, and epilepsy. It is caused by somatic mosaicism of an activating mutation in the GNAQ gene. This patient’s eye examination shows absent iris rather than glaucoma.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old man comes to the clinic because of vague right-sided back pain over the past two months. He denies any recent trauma, heavy lifting, or new activity. The patient has also noticed a 4.2 kg weight loss during this time, despite not making any changes to diet or activity. The patient has a 20 pack-year smoking history. The patient’s temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 128/85 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The results of his urinalysis are shown below:  
 
Laboratory value   Result 
 Urinalysis 
 Erythrocytes  60/hpf 
 Leukocytes  4/hpf 
 Bacteria  None 
Which of the following is a possible complication of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has renal cell carcinoma (RCC) based on his vague right-sided flank pain, weight loss, hematuria, and low-grade fever. He is also a male between the ages of 50-70 years with a history of smoking, which are significant risk factors for RCC.  

Among the answers above, only polycythemia is associated with RCC, which is secondary to paraneoplastic ectopic production of erythropoietin (EPO). Paraneoplastic syndromes associated with RCC are the consequence of ectopic hormone production, namely EPO, parathyroid hormone-related protein (PTHrP), adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), and renin. Symptoms of polycythemia may include headache, dizziness, visual disturbances, pruritus, or complications such as thrombosis and bleeding. Additionally, patients may present with intense itching after a hot shower. Laboratory findings include a high hematocrit and hemoglobin.  

Clear cell RCC is the most common subtype of RCC, which can arise sporadically or can be hereditary as a part of Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome. It is the most common primary tumor of the kidneys, arising from the cells of the proximal collecting ducts of the nephron. Histologically, it is composed of polygonal clear cells filled with lipids and carbohydrates that often appear golden yellow. RCC is unique as it first metastasizes hematogenously via the renal vein.  

Option Analysis

❌ Hypertrophic osteoarthropathy:
Incorrect: Hypertrophic osteoarthropathy is a possible complication of adenocarcinoma of the lung. This condition causes clubbing and periostitis of the hand, especially the distal interphalangeal joints and the metacarpophalangeal joints.  


Reproduced from: Radiopaedia  
Hypertrophic osteoarthropathy  
❌ Dermatomyositis:
Incorrect: Dermatomyositis is a possible complication of adenocarcinomas, especially ovarian. It presents with progressive proximal muscle weakness, gottron papules, and a heliotrope rash.  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons  
Heliotrope rash  



Reproduced from:Wikimedia Commons  
Gottron papules  
❌ Opsoclonus myoclonus ataxia syndrome:
Incorrect: Opsoclonus myoclonus ataxia syndrome presents with diffuse or focal myoclonus, truncal titubation, ataxia and ocular motility defects, and it is associated with neuroblastoma (in children) and small cell lung cancer (in adults); the syndrome can also be seen in other conditions (e.g., viral infections, post-streptococcal pharyngitis, hemorrhage). The syndrome is often referred to as “dancing eyes, dancing feet” because of the unique findings of ataxia and ocular motility disorder seen in these patients.   
✅ Polycythemia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hyponatremia:
Incorrect: Hyponatremia can be caused by the syndrome of inappropriate ADH (SIADH) secretion, which is associated with small cell lung cancer.  
❌ Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome:
Incorrect: Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome occurs when antibodies are produced against the presynaptic (P/Q-type) Ca2+ channels at the neuromuscular junction. It is characterized by proximal muscle weakness and autonomic symptoms that classically improve with use (in contrast with myasthenia gravis). The syndrome is associated with small cell lung cancer.

questions.text:
An 83-year-old man comes to the office for a routine evaluation. The patient recently noticed that his urine has pinkish tinge, but he denies dysuria or abdominal pain. Medical history is unremarkable, and physical examination shows no abnormalities. Repeated urinalysis shows 5-10 RBC/hpf, and the urine is pinkish-red in color. Cystoscopy with biopsy is obtained, and the results are shown below.  

 

Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following is the most common risk factor associated with this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with painless gross hematuria, a classic presentation of bladder cancer. The biopsy results confirm the diagnosis of transitional cell carcinoma.   

In the industrialized world, about 90% of bladder cancers are transitional cell carcinoma, also known as urothelial cell carcinoma. Squamous cell carcinoma accounts for up to 7% of bladder cancers in the United States but is much more common in countries where schistosomiasis is endemic (e.g. Egypt). Adenocarcinomas of the bladder are rare. Up to 80% of bladder cancer cases are associated with an environmental exposure. Tobacco use is by far the most common cause of transitional cell bladder cancer in the United States and is increasing in importance in some developing countries. Smoking duration and intensity are directly related to increased risk. Tobacco use is also associated with squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder but to a lesser extent. Other risk factors include exposure to aromatic amines, phenacetin, pelvic radiation, and treatment with cyclophosphamide.  

In patients presenting with painless, gross hematuria, bladder cancer should be suspected, and  cystoscopy should be performed.   

Option Analysis

❌ Exposure to aromatic amines:
Incorrect: Exposure to aromatic amines such as benzidine in the paint industry does increase the risk for bladder cancer; however, tobacco use is the most common cause of bladder cancer.   
❌ Pelvic radiation:
Incorrect: Pelvic radiation has been associated with an increased risk for bladder cancer. However, this relationship has not been established in all studies, and the magnitude of the risk appears to be minute. Tobacco use is the most common cause of bladder cancer.  
❌ Recurrent urinary tract infections:
Incorrect: Recurrent urinary tract infections may increase the risk for pyelonephritis. While chronic urinary irritation may cause squamous metaplasia and squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder, this process is not the most common risk factor for bladder cancer.  
✅ Smoking history:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Cyclophosphamide use:
While cyclophosphamide is a risk factor for hemorrhagic cystitis and bladder cancer, tobacco use is the most common cause of bladder cancer. The risk of bladder cancer in patients taking cyclophosphamide can be reduced with the co-administration of mesna.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male comes to the physician’s office due to scrotal pain for the past 2 weeks. The patient describes a dull pain and noticed that his scrotum appears larger. He also felt fatigued and hot for the past 2 months and thinks that his vision has become blurrier. Medical history is significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. The patient has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes per day for 30 years. Medications include lovastatin and ramipril. The patient’s temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 145/85 mmHg. Physical examination reveals facial flushing. Examination of the scrotum shows left side swelling which is not reduced when the patient is lying down. When light is applied to the testicle it does not transilluminate. This patient’s underlying condition most likely originated from which of the following areas?
questions.solution:
This patient has a significant smoking history and hypertension, and he is now presenting with fatigue, low-grade fever, and blurry vision. This presentation, along with the physical exam showing testicular swelling that is not reduced when lying, is suggestive of a renal tumor. Varicoceles that fail to empty when the patient is recumbent are highly suspicious for a kidney tumor that obstructs the gonadal vein where it enters the renal vein. The facial flushing, hypertension and blurry vision are most likely secondary to ectopic production of erythropoietin by the renal tumor.   

Renal cell carcinomas (RCCs) are the most common primary tumors of the kidney, originating from the proximal convoluted tubules within the renal cortex. Transitional cell carcinomas of the renal pelvis are the second most common. Patients with RCC can present with a variety of symptoms, but unfortunately, such symptoms usually occur late in the course, when metastasis has already occurred. The classic triad of RCC includes flank pain, hematuria, and palpable abdominal renal mass. Hematuria occurs when the tumor invades the collecting system. When the tumor invades the inferior vena cava, it may lead to lower extremity edema, ascites, hepatic dysfunction (related to Budd-Chiari syndrome), and pulmonary emboli. RCC can cause various paraneoplastic syndromes including polycythemia/ erythrocytosis (due to EPO production), hypercalcemia (due to PTHrP production). Increased incidence of RCC is associated with smoking and obesity.   

Option Analysis

❌ Bone marrow:
Incorrect: Polycythemia vera is a myeloproliferative disorder in which the bone marrow makes too many red blood cells. Occasionally, the condition may result in the overproduction of white blood cells and platelets as well. Although this patient’s hypertension, blurry vision, and facial flushing can also be seen in polycythemia vera, varicoceles are not expected.   
❌ Testicles:
Incorrect: Testicular tumors also do not transilluminate, but these tumors usually present with a testicular mass rather than swelling. Also, a testicular tumor would not explain the patient’s hypertension, facial flushing, and blurry vision.   
✅ Kidney:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Lung:
Incorrect: Lung tumors are not associated with polycythemia as a paraneoplastic syndrome, and therefore, they will not cause facial flushing or blurry vision. Also, a lung tumor would not explain the patient's testicular findings.   
❌ Bone:
Incorrect: Bone tumors are not associated with polycythemia as a paraneoplastic syndrome, and therefore, they will not cause facial flushing or blurry vision. Also, a bone tumor would not explain the patient's testicular findings.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician's office for a follow-up appointment after a car accident that required hospitalization. The patient was in the car accident 1 month ago, and he broke 2 ribs on the left side. During the hospitalization, a focused assessment with sonography in trauma (FAST) was obtained, and an incidental renal finding that was suspicious of a cyst was observed. The patient's medical history is unremarkable, and the patient reports that he feels well. Which of the following features if observed on imaging will favor the diagnosis of a benign lesion?

choices.text: Strong posterior wall echo on ultrasound
The presence of echoes within the mass on ultrasound
An enhancement of soft-tissue components with CT contrast
Irregular borders of the lesion on CT scan
Nodular calcification of the wall on CT scan

questions.solution:
Renal cysts can be categorized as simple or complex. Simple renal cysts are often observed in normal kidneys of healthy individuals, and the incidence increases with age (>50 years old). Simple renal cysts are benign, asymptomatic lesions that rarely require treatment. In contrast, complex cysts usually require follow-up imaging, biopsy, or surgical excision in order to exclude malignancy.  

The first step in evaluation is ultrasound, which helps to differentiate a cyst from malignancy or abscess as following:  

  •  Round mass, sharply demarcated with smooth walls. 
  •  No echoes (anechoic) within the mass. 
  •  Strong posterior wall echo, indicating good transmission through the cyst. 
If all three components of the criteria are satisfied, further evaluation is not necessary, since the likelihood of malignancy is low. If the results of the ultrasonogram are equivocal, if calcifications or septae are seen, or if multiple cysts could mask an underlying carcinoma, a CT scan should follow.  

A simple renal cyst is considered to be present if the following features are observed on CT scan:    

  •  A sharply demarcated lesion with a smooth, thin wall. 
  •  Homogeneous fluid within the cyst is, with a density of <20 Hounsfield units (similar to water).  
  •  No enhancement of the mass following the administration of contrast, indicating an avascular lesion. Enhancement implies vascularity, which is a characteristic of a malignant lesion.  
Findings suggestive of malignancy include thickened, irregular or smooth walls or septa and enhancement following contrast injection.  

 


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons  
Simple renal cyst on ultrasound  



Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons  
Complex renal cyst on ultrasound  



Option Analysis

✅ Strong posterior wall echo on ultrasound:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ The presence of echoes within the mass on ultrasound:
Incorrect: Echoes within the mass on ultrasound are characteristic of a complex cyst, which requires further evaluation. Highly dense tissues, such as solid components, readily reflect echoes and appear bright white on an ultrasound.  
❌ An enhancement of soft-tissue components with CT contrast:
Incorrect: An enhancement of soft-tissue components with contrast indicates vascular lesion, which prompts further evaluation. Vascularity is a characteristic of a malignant lesion.   
❌ Irregular borders of the lesion on CT scan:
Incorrect: Irregular borders of the lesion are characteristic of a complex cyst that prompts further evaluation.   
❌ Nodular calcification of the wall on CT scan:
Incorrect: Nodular calcification of the wall is a feature of a complex cyst that requires further evaluation.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old man comes to the clinic due to burning urination for the past 3 weeks. The patient recently returned from a trip to Egypt, where he hiked and swam in freshwater. During that time, the patient developed an itchy rash over some parts of the body, which self-resolved after a few days. Medical history is unremarkable besides a gonorrhea infection 3 years ago, which was successfully treated with antibiotics. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Complete blood count shows:  
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Hemoglobin  12 g/dL 
 Hematocrit  40% 
 Leukocyte count  12,100/mm3 
 Platelet count  400,000/mm3 
 Neutrophils, segmented  54% 
 Neutrophils, banded  5% 
 Eosinophils  12% 
 Basophils  0% 
 Lymphocytes  25% 
 Monocytes  7% 
Urine sample is obtained and the specimen under light microscopy is shown below:    


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons  
If left untreated, this patient is most likely to develop which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
This patient, who has a history of traveling to endemic areas (i.e., Egypt), an itchy rash that appeared after swimming, followed by dysuria, as well as eosinophilia and consistent urinalysis findings, most likely has schistosomiasis. His urinalysis shows the classic appearance of Schistosoma haematobium.  

These parasites live in certain types of freshwater snails. Cercariae, the infectious form of the parasite, emerge from the snail and contaminate the water. Infection occurs through penetration of the skin. After entering the body, the cercariae shed their tails, and become schistosomula, which migrate through the circulation to the liver, where they mature into adults. The adult worms migrate against portal blood flow to the mesenteric venules of the intestine, the mesenteric venules of the colon, or the vesical venous plexus. The males form a groove in which the females reside and deposit the eggs. The eggs travel to the lumen of the intestine (S. mansoni and S. japonicum) or bladder and ureters (S. haematobium) and are excreted in feces or urine.  

The entrapped eggs secrete proteins and carbohydrates that induce a host TH2 immune response, which results in an eosinophilic granulomatous reaction and subsequent tissue inflammation and fibrosis. In the bowel, this inflammation can result in ulceration, blood loss, and scarring. In the liver, the infection can cause periportal fibrosis, portal hypertension, and subsequent esophageal varices. In the bladder, it can result in the development of pseudopolyps and cancer. Specifically, S. haematobium is associated with squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder. Treatment includes praziquantel.    

Option Analysis

❌ Aortitis:
Incorrect: Aortitis, inflammation of the aorta, is a complication of untreated syphilis infection. The first sign of syphilis infection is the appearance of a nontender chancre on the genitals. Aortitis is a late complication seen years later. Syphilis spirochetes can only be visualized under dark-field microscopy, not light microscopy. Also, syphilis causes leukocytosis with neutrophil predominance, not eosinophilia.  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons 
❌ Rapidly fatal meningoencephalitis :
Incorrect: Rapidly fatal meningoencephalitis is a complication of the protozoa Naegleria fowleri, which is also acquired through swimming in warm freshwater. The protozoa enter the CNS via the cribriform plate.  Diagnosis is made through CSF analysis. This patient’s presentation and findings favor another diagnosis.   
✅ Bladder cancer:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Liver abscess:
Incorrect: Liver abscess is a complication of the GI protozoa, Entamoeba histolytica, which is acquired through ingestion of cysts found in water. It is prevalent in tropical areas with poor sanitation. Infection can be asymptomatic or can lead to fulminate dysentery, bloody diarrhea, weight loss, fatigue, and abdominal pain. Diagnosis can be made by serology, antigen testing, and/or visualizing trophozoites (with engulfed RBCs in the cytoplasm) or cysts containing 4 nuclei in the stool.  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons  
Trophozoites with engulfed RBCs  
❌ Swelling in skin :
Incorrect: Swelling of the skin (elephantiasis) is a complication of the parasitic worm Loa loa found in certain rain forests of West and Central Africa. It can also cause blindness. It is transmitted by deer fly, horse fly, and mango fly to the human host through the bite wound. Diagnosis is typically made by visualizing microfilaria of Loa loa in a thin blood smear.


Reproduced from: CDC  
Microfilaria of Loa loa in a thin blood smear

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl is brought to the pediatrician by her parents for a well child visit. She has been meeting all developmental milestones. Vitals are within normal range. The patient is well-appearing and cooperative. Physical examination reveals a mass in the left abdomen. A CT scan is performed and shows a unilateral heterogeneous renal mass. A biopsy is taken, and the patient is diagnosed with a stage II Wilms tumor. The tumor is resected, and the patient is started on a chemotherapeutic agent that works by binding with DNA and preventing RNA synthesis. The new agent does not interfere with topoisomerase activity. Which of the following side effects is associated with this medication?
questions.solution:
This patient was diagnosed with Wilms tumor, also termed nephroblastoma, and started on actinomycin D.

Actinomycin D is an antitumor antibiotic that intercalates with DNA and prevents DNA-dependent RNA polymerase from binding, thereby inhibiting RNA synthesis. This, in turn, halts RNA protein synthesis, ultimately leading to cellular arrest and inhibition of cellular division. In addition, actinomycin D can generate free radicals to cause DNA strand breaks. Actinomycin D is frequently used to treat pediatric tumors, such as Wilms tumor, rhabdomyosarcoma, and Ewing sarcoma.

Side effects of actinomycin D include bone marrow suppression, alopecia, as well as hepatotoxicity. Liver injury associated with actinomycin D can range from asymptomatic elevation of liver enzymes, which is usually transient and resolves without intervention, to fulminant liver injury, which can be severe and fatal.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Hematuria:
Incorrect: Hemorrhagic cystitis is a known complication of cyclophosphamide. It usually presents with hematuria, dysuria, and suprapubic pain. It is not a side effect of this medication.  
✅ Elevation of liver enzymes:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Peripheral sensory neuropathy:
Incorrect: Chemotherapeutic agents such as paclitaxel, cisplatin, and vincristine are associated with neurotoxicity, which usually manifests as peripheral neuropathy. However, this patient was most likely started on actinomycin D. Actinomycin D does not typically cause peripheral neuropathy.  
❌ Pulmonary fibrosis:
Incorrect: Pulmonary fibrosis is a side effect of the chemotherapeutic agents bleomycin and busulfan. It is not a side effect of this medication.  
❌ Dilated cardiomyopathy:
Incorrect: Doxorubicin is known to cause irreversible cardiotoxicity. This can result in dilated cardiomyopathy and heart failure. Although doxorubicin can intercalate with DNA, this medication also works by inhibiting the enzyme topoisomerase II.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents to the clinic due to intermittent blood in his urine. The patient first noticed it 3 months ago, and it is becoming more frequent. The patient has also unintentionally lost 20 pounds over the past 3 months. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, and current medications include amlodipine and carvedilol. The patient has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes per day for the past 50 years. Computed tomography (CT) of the abdomen shows a 4 cm mass in the left kidney. A biopsy is taken and shows renal cell carcinoma. CT of the chest is subsequently performed and shows multiple metastatic lesions in the bilateral lungs. The patient is started on a medication that stimulates cytotoxic T-cell proliferation and activation. Which of the following medications is being given to this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient, who presented with gross hematuria and unintentional weight loss, has been diagnosed with metastatic renal cell carcinoma (RCC). RCC typically occurs in patients older than 50 (median age around 64 years old), and is more common in men than women. Smoking is a known risk factor for RCC.    

Aldessleukin, a recombinant interleukin-2,  is an immunomodulating agent used in the treatment of metastatic RCC and melanoma. It exerts its antitumor effects by stimulating IL-2 receptors, leading to activation and proliferation of cytotoxic T lymphocytes and natural killer cells. This helps the immune system fight against cancerous cells. Recombinant IL-2 can also promote the secretion of secondary cytokines, further improving the immune response.  

The side effects of recombinant interleukin-2 are usually dose-dependent, and can be reversed with dose reduction or stopping the medication. These side effects include hypotension, peripheral edema, and weight gain. Additionally, some patients have experienced neurotoxicity or acute kidney injury as a result of using recombinant IL-2.  

Option Analysis

✅ Aldesleukin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Basiliximab:
Incorrect: Basiliximab is a monoclonal antibody against the interleukin-2 (IL-2) receptor. By blocking IL-2R, it prevents the proliferation of lymphocytes and suppresses the immune response. 
❌ Anakinra:
Incorrect: Anakinra is an interleukin-1 receptor antagonist. It blocks and prevents the proliferation of lymphocytes and depresses their cytotoxic ability. 
❌ Infliximab:
Incorrect: Infliximab is a monoclonal antibody that works against soluble tumor necrosis factor-alpha. It suppresses the immune response and lymphocyte activation and is used in certain autoimmune disorders (e.g. Crohn’s disease)
❌ Etanercept:
Incorrect: Etanercept is a fusion protein that binds to and sequesters tumor necrosis factor alpha, thereby preventing its action in stimulating the immune response and leukocyte activation.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the physician for lower back pain. The pain started six months ago and is worse at night. Physical examination reveals tenderness in the lumbar region of the vertebral column. MRI of the lumbar spine shows neoplastic masses. On additional evaluation, the patient is found to have metastatic prostate cancer. The physician decides to start the patient on a medication that blocks testosterone receptors on the tumor cells. Which of the following side effects is this patient at risk for due to this medication?
questions.solution:
This patient with metastatic prostate cancer is started on a testosterone receptor blocker, flutamide, as part of the treatment. Hepatotoxicity is a possible side effect of this medication.

Androgens stimulate the growth of the prostate cells and can also induce the growth of prostate cancer; therefore, anti-androgens used in managing prostate cancer inhibit tumor growth. Flutamide is one such anti-androgen that blocks testosterone receptors on the tumor cells, thereby inhibiting the proliferation of the tumor. Due to its anti-androgen effects, flutamide is also sometimes used in managing hirsutism in women and hair loss in men.

The most common side effect of flutamide is hot flashes, usually seen in more than 50% of the population. Also, decreased libido, vomiting, and gynecomastia can be seen. One of the most severe and feared side effects of flutamide is hepatotoxicity. It usually happens secondary to mitochondrial injury of hepatocytes, causing cholestatic hepatitis and, ultimately, hepatic failure. Therefore, patients with severe liver injury must avoid using flutamide.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Hepatotoxicity:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Pulmonary fibrosis:
Incorrect: Certain medications (e.g., bleomycin, amiodarone) can cause pulmonary fibrosis as a side effect. It is not associated with flutamide.  
❌ Heart failure:
Incorrect: Thiazolidinediones can increase the risk of inducing or worsening heart failure. Flutamide is not directly related to the development of heart failure.  
❌ Hemochromatosis:
Incorrect: Exogenous androgen abuse can lead to hemochromatosis. However, flutamide is a testosterone receptor blocker and does not cause hemochromatosis.  
❌ Nephrotoxicity:
Incorrect: Flutamide is not known to cause nephrotoxicity.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presents to the oncology clinic to discuss a recent diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma. Medical history is otherwise significant for hypertension, for which the patient takes lisinopril. Family history is significant for renal cell carcinoma in the patient’s father. Vital signs are within normal limits, and physical examination is unremarkable. The patient asks the oncologist why his “immune system is not attacking the cancer.” The oncologist explains several immune system regulators, such as the programmed death-1 ligand and receptor (PDL1 and PD-1, respectively) and cytotoxic T-lymphocyte-associated protein 4 (CTLA-4). Which of the following correctly describes how the cancer cells could be evading the immune system?

choices.text: CD28 on cancer cells binds CTLA-4 on T-cells
CTLA-4 on cancer cells binds CD28 on T-cells
PD-1 ligands on cancer cells bind PD-1 receptors on immune cells
PD-1 receptors on cancer cells bind PD-1 ligands on immune cells
p53 protein upregulation by cancer cells

questions.solution:
There are many ways tumor cells can evade the immune system. Normally, the immune system has several “checkpoint” functions that help prevent it from attacking its cells. Immune cells, such as regulatory T-lymphocytes, play a crucial role in this process. Several examples of regulatory checkpoints include co-stimulation signals for activation, programmed cell death, and downregulation of T-lymphocytes. Tumor cells can exploit these by expressing molecules that prevent their destruction by downregulating these regulatory immune cells.

One common example is the programmed death-1 pathway. Normally the PD-1 ligand (PDL1) is expressed in cells such as T-cells and NK cells. It binds to the PD-1 receptor (PD-1) on activated T-cells and B-cells to downregulate activated T-cells while promoting regulatory T-cells. 

Over the last decade, many new immunotherapy medications have been developed and approved for use as immune checkpoint inhibitors in cancers. Several examples include CTLA-4 inhibitors (e.g. ipilimumab), PDL1 inhibitors (e.g. atezolizumab) and PD-1 inhibitors (e.g. nivolumab, pembrolizumab).   

Option Analysis

❌ CD28 on cancer cells binds CTLA-4 on T-cells :
Incorrect: CD28 is a receptor found on T-cells that binds to CD80 (B7) for co-stimulatory signaling activation. CTLA-4 competes with CD28 to downregulate T-cell activation. CD28 does not bind to CTLA-4 (they are homologous receptors). 
❌ CTLA-4 on cancer cells binds CD28 on T-cells :
Incorrect: CD28 is a receptor found on T-cells that binds to CD80 (B7) for co-stimulatory signaling activation of T-cells. CTLA-4 competes with CD28 to downregulate T-cell activation. CD28 does not bind to CTLA-4 (they are homologous receptors). 
✅ PD-1 ligands on cancer cells bind PD-1 receptors on immune cells :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ PD-1 receptors on cancer cells bind PD-1 ligands on immune cells :
Incorrect: Cancer cells generally produce the PD-1 ligand, which binds to PD-1 receptors on T-cells, downregulating their activity. PDL1 expression on tumor cells can often be measured.  
❌ p53 protein upregulation by cancer cells :
Incorrect: p53 is a regulatory protein involved in DNA repair, apoptosis, and others. In general, it has anti-cancer properties (as it does things such as inhibit tumor angiogenesis).

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being involved in a motor vehicle collision. The patient complains of pain on the left side of the chest that gets worse on deep breathing. Temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 104/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mmHg. Physical examination shows bruising and tenderness over the left posterior chest wall. The spinal range of motion is normal, and there is no midline tenderness. The gross motor and neurological examination is within normal limits. Plain chest radiograph reveals a left-sided 12th rib fracture. This patient is at increased risk of injury to which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
This patient with a left 12th rib fracture is at risk of left kidney laceration.   

The chest comprises 12 rib bones on each side of the body. Each rib attaches to the spine at the back of the body and then travels around to the front of the chest. The top 7 ribs attach to the sternum, the 8th to 10th ribs attach to the ribs above via cartilage, and the 11th and 12th ribs are known as ‘floating’ ribs as they are unattached at the front of the chest.   

Rib fractures are the most common injury sustained in blunt thoracic trauma. Fractures may cause localized pain, crepitus, pain with inspiration, dyspnea, and may even cause pneumothorax or hemothorax. The left 12th rib overlies the parietal pleura medially and the left kidney laterally. Therefore, the distal tip of the left rib can displace into the retroperitoneum and lacerate the left kidney.   

Option Analysis

❌ Brachial plexus:
Incorrect: The brachial plexus extends from the spinal cord, through the cervicoaxillary canal in the neck, over the first rib, and into the armpit. It is susceptible to injury in cases of 1st-3rd rib fractures.  
❌ Subclavian artery:
Incorrect: The subclavian artery travels laterally, passing between anterior and middle scalene muscles, with the anterior scalene on its anterior side and the middle scalene on its posterior. As the subclavian artery crosses the lateral border of the first rib, it becomes the axillary artery. It would not be affected by 12th rib fractures.  
✅ Left kidney:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Pancreas:
Incorrect: The pancreas is a retroperitoneal organ that stretches from behind the stomach to the left upper abdomen near the spleen. It overlies the body of the second lumbar vertebrae. It is most susceptible to injury with a crushing abdominal trauma.   
❌ Spleen:
Incorrect: The spleen is underneath the left part of the diaphragm and the ninth, tenth, and eleventh ribs on the left side. It is less likely to be injured in 12th rib fracture.

questions.text:
A 43-year-old woman comes to the office because of blood in her urine. The patient reports intermittent painless hematuria associated with mild to moderate left lumbar pain and nausea for the last three months. She does not have dysuria, urinary frequency, or urinary urgency. Past medical history is significant for major depression, and the patient reports that she has lost a lot of weight over the past few months. Family history is unremarkable. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a nontender, nondistended abdomen. Lungs and cardiovascular examination are within normal limits. Urinalysis shows 15–20 Er/Hpf and no proteinuria. An abdominal CT is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s presentation?  


Reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a recent history of significant weight loss presents with intermittent gross hematuria and lumbar pain. The abdominal CT scan demonstrates left renal vein compression at its distal segment between the aorta and the superior mesenteric artery with mild proximal dilatation. In combination, this presentation is consistent with nutcracker syndrome (NCS).  

NCS occurs when the left renal vein, which drains blood from the left kidney, becomes squeezed between the superior mesenteric artery (SMA) and abdominal aorta. Normally, the aortomesenteric angle (between SMA and aorta) is around 45 degrees, with the renal vein cushioned by a bit of fat in the mesentery. If there is significant weight loss which shrinks the mesenteric fat, this angle is reduced, and the arteries begin to pinch the left renal vein, causing renal hypertension. Over time, the high pressures cause small breaks in the renal blood vessels. Patients typically present with gross hematuria and left flank pain that may improve or worsen depending on positioning.  

Since the left gonadal vein drains via the left renal vein, nutcracker syndrome can also result in left testicular pain in males or left lower quadrant pain in females, especially during intercourse and during menstruation. An unusual manifestation of NCS includes varicocele formation and varicose veins in the lower limbs.  



Option Analysis

❌ Ureteric stone:
Incorrect: Ureteric stones lie within the ureter at any point from the ureteropelvic junction (UPJ) to the vesicoureteric junction (VUJ). They are the classic cause of renal colic-type abdominal pain. Although it may cause hematuria and flank pain, CT scan would show an opacity in the ureter, rather than left renal vein compression.  
❌ Pelvic congestion syndrome:
Incorrect: Pelvic congestion syndrome in women is believed to be due to enlarged veins in the lower abdomen secondary to blood flowing back into pelvic veins.The condition may cause chronic pain, such as a constant dull ache, which can be worsened by standing or sexual intercourse. Gross hematuria is typically absent.  
❌ Superior mesenteric artery syndrome:
Incorrect: Superior mesenteric artery (SMA) syndrome occurs when the transverse portion of the duodenum is entrapped between the SMA and aorta, causing symptoms of bowel obstruction. Gross hematuria is not typically seen.  
✅ Nutcracker syndrome:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Renal artery stenosis:
Incorrect: Renal artery stenosis is the narrowing of one or both of the renal arteries, most often caused by atherosclerosis or fibromuscular dysplasia. Patients typically present with elevated blood pressure that is not controlled by medications. Physical examination may show a bruit over the renal artery on auscultation. This patient’s vitals are within normal limits.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man admitted to the inpatient wards presents with hematuria. He has not had dysuria, straining, polyuria, abdominal pain, or fever. His medical history includes chronic lymphocytic leukemia, for which he underwent a bone marrow transplant two weeks ago, type II diabetes mellitus, and chronic back pain. Before his transplant, he was treated with an antineoplastic drug that induces DNA damage by creating interstrand cross-links. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 145/75 mmHg. Abdominal examination is unremarkable. Which of the following findings are expected on urinalysis?

choices.text: Protein  Dysmorphic RBCs  Casts  Cells/Crystals  +3 Absent Fatty castsEpithelial cells with oval fat bodies

questions.solution:
This patient presents with hematuria following initiation of a chemotherapeutic regimen suggestive of hemorrhagic cystitis secondary to cyclophosphamide use.   

Cyclophosphamide is nitrogen mustard used for conditioning before hematopoietic stem cell transplant (HSCT). Its mechanism of action involves the creation of cross-links between interstrand guanine bases of DNA, resulting in DNA damage and impairment of replication and repair. Cyclophosphamide is associated with adverse effects, including alopecia, GI disturbances, myelosuppression, hemorrhagic cystitis, gonadal toxicity, infertility, teratogenic effects, and SIADH.  

Hemorrhagic cystitis, following the use of nitrogen mustards like cyclophosphamide and ifosfamide, is an inflammatory process induced by a toxic metabolite called acrolein. The liver metabolizes Cyclophosphamide, and acrolein is formed as a metabolic product. This substance is then filtered by the kidneys and concentrated in the bladder, where it promotes production of proinflammatory cytokines, generates reactive oxygen species, and production of nitric oxide. These compounds damage the urothelium, resulting in hemorrhage and edema. Forced saline diuresis, aggressive hydration, and pretreatment with MESNA are indicated in all patients receiving cyclophosphamide.  

Option Analysis

❌  Protein  Dysmorphic RBCs  Casts  Cells/Crystals  Absent  Absent  White blood cell casts  White blood cells  :
Incorrect: WBC casts in conjunction with clinical findings of fever, dysuria, and flank pain suggest pyelonephritis. 
✅  Protein  Dysmorphic RBCs  Casts  Cells/Crystals  Absent  Absent Absent Erythrocytes:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌  Protein  Dysmorphic RBCs  Casts  Cells/Crystals  +3 Absent Fatty castsEpithelial cells with oval fat bodies:
Incorrect: Proteinuria, fatty casts, and oval fat bodies indicate a diagnosis of nephrotic syndrome. 
❌  Protein  Dysmorphic RBCs  Casts  Cells/Crystals  Absent PresentRed blood cell castsNone:
Incorrect:  Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis can result in the presence of red blood cell casts and dysmorphic red blood cells. 
❌  Protein  Dysmorphic RBCs  Casts  Cells/Crystals  Absent  Absent Absent Envelope-shaped crystals, Erythrocytes:
Incorrect:  Envelope-shaped crystals are indicative of calcium oxalate calculi.
